sub_topic: Calculation of the Bohr radius in hydrogen atom
message_1: What is the Bohr radius of the hydrogen atom in meters, given its mass and fundamental constants? Calculate the answer and provide it in scientific notation to three significant figures.
message_2:
The Bohr radius (a0) of the hydrogen atom is given by the formula:

a0 = (4πε0ħ²) / (me²)

where ε0 is the vacuum permittivity, ħ is the reduced Planck constant, me is the mass of the electron, and e is the elementary charge.

The values of these constants are:

ε0 = 8.854 x 10⁻¹² F/m (Farads per meter)
ħ = 1.055 x 10⁻³⁴ J·s (Joule-seconds)
me = 9.109 x 10⁻³¹ kg (kilograms)
e = 1.602 x 10⁻¹⁹ C (Coulombs)

Plugging these values into the formula:

a0 = (4π(8.854 x 10⁻¹²)(1.055 x 10⁻³⁴)²) / ((9.109 x 10⁻³¹)(1.602 x 10⁻¹⁹)²)

a0 ≈ 5.291 x 10⁻¹¹ m

So, the Bohr radius of the hydrogen atom is approximately 5.29 x 10⁻¹¹ meters.
